I've only gotten delivery from this Sultan's location, and while the food is good, it often arrives cold once it gets to my place (I think they use bike messengers for delivery). We've also not gotten our full orders when getting delivery, so main reasons for 4/5 instead of 5/5. Otherwise, cucumber salad is randomly better here than the one on North Ave., but I would rather go the extra mile(s) to dine-in in at the North Ave. location than get delivery from this one.

Stopped in for a light dinner late Friday. Tried the falafel sandwich and was impressed with the quality of food for the price. For $4 and change you get a giant falafel sandwich filled with hummus, cucumber salad, falafel, onion and tomato. Was a very filling meal but slightly bland; could have used some sauce. Will try the lamb shawerma meal next time (only $7)

This place is nice if you're on the go and want so good mediter. food. However if you're looking for top notch mediter. food, this isn't really the place. I've had better hummus and better falafel (i really wanted to love this place, i promise) and the grilled chicken was alright. The cucumber sauce had gone bad the next day too (weird). However, I will say that their babaganoush is very good, no bitter notes at all like alot of baba does (when done badly). So if you're in a hurry this place is good, but I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here, maybe just go in and grab some baba to go.

I want to eat Sultan's every day. It's priced right, delicious, and they deliver really fast! Their hummus is very tasty and fresh. The chicken shawarma dinner is my favorite. I always make my own little pita sandwich using the dinner ingredients. It's one of my top places to go in Chicago. My favorite part is that I get to eat something delicious and so do my vegetarian & vegan friends when we do a lunch date! And they're open pretty late on Fridays and Saturdays. I think they deliver until midnight or something like that. Totally rules!

Their chicken shawarma sandwiches are the bomb diggity.  I could eat one every day.  Throw in a piece of baklava for dessert and I couldn't be more satisfied. Cheap mediterranean food that is delicious and only 2 blocks from my apartment -- what more could you ask for??

popped in for lunch on my day off...the falafel was good as peeps say.  i decided to try the lamb shawarma.  i shouldnt have, chicken seems to go better in shawarma.  the chicken definitely looked nice and juicy on the spit.  its good, its cheap, but ive had better...and the garlic spread was lacking in flavor.  this place is tiny but perfect for a lunch drive-by or carry-out

Though I like the Wicker Park location, this location is much closer to me and hence the one I frequent.  Great prices, amazing food.  You can get a dinner including hummus, jerusalem salad, pita chicken and lentil rice for just 7$.  Aaaand, it's delish.  They also have bar of sides that you can pick and choose from for x$ per/lb but I haven't tried it. The seating is really tight and just doesn't feel comfortable, but at the speed at which i usually devour this meal it doesn't really matter.
I love the falafel.   Inside is absolutely tiny. But overall, best falafel I've had in awhile!

Putting out great Mediterranean Food, Sultan's Market sits in with a whole strip of other boutiques and restaurants.  Meals are relatively low priced and portions are perfect.  Perfect spot for your quick Mediterranean fix.

This location is superior to the other even though it is tiny and dining in is unbelievably awkward. The tables are so close you can barely sit without touching your neighbor. That being said, when it's nice out they have a couple tables outside, if you're into that.  The falafel is perfectly seasoned and never dry or greasy and I've never gotten an underfilled sandwich here. In fact a couple of the guys are so good they make it so I have falafel in every bite. I love you falafel guys, never change. This is definitely a spot to stop by when broke/cheap and hungry in lp.

Having seen Sultan's near a friend's house, I've been curious about this place for a long time. On a cold, rainy night we picked up our wedding rings nearvy and needed some food. The mister has been a frequent patron of its other location, so I figured it must be good. For my dinner, I had the chicken schwarma platter with an extra falalel while the mister had the three meats one. Honestly, it's good Mediterranean food, just not the best that I've experienced. It satisfied on a cold night for sure. I don't think that I would make it destination dining where I have to eat there, but if it's there, I'll gladly enjoy it.
Nothing but good things to say, fast service, delicious food, low prices. I just wish there was one closer to my house! Oh well, it gives me somewhere to ride my bike to...

The Sultan introduced me to some amazing hummus!  At work we celebrated the kick off of National Vegetarian month, which begins Oct. 1. Sultan Market hooked us up. We quoted for enough food to feed 100 and I'm not kidding when I say we had enough food to feed 300 or more. There were so many leftovers I was begging people to take. Thank goodness it went over so well because no one had a problem taking the food home. We had curry rice, lentil rice, two salads (one I thought tasted like grass), falafel, pita, and hummus. We also had a spicy chicken dish for the meat eaters. I heard that the chicken was a really spicy and we had a couple of complaints but for the most part everyone loved it. Also the price we got for all the food was amazing and super cheap. I'm only giving it 4 stars though because the delivery didn't go that smoothly. We ended up have to cart all the food up ourselves because the delivery guy was not prepared.

I bought a coupon on Groupon for the Clark location. Not realizing it expired Friday Sept. 25, on Saturday morning 10.15 am I called information to get the Clark phone number; fyi they are not listed w/411 so i called the North Ave location. The young guy who answered was cool. I explained what happened he said "no problem it is less than 12 hrs just go to the Clark location and they will be fine". Well they were not some middle eastern man answered the phone was a complete ASS! He told me NO it expired yesterday too bad! While I tried to explain to him that North Ave said it would be OK he said 'GO TO NORTH AVE THEN "and then hung up on me. Yes I am at fault for not paying attention to the expiration date but I'll be damned if I'll let anyone hang up on me, I will never ever go to either of their shops after this. Should I remind these restaurants that word of mouth goes a long way.

I had some groupons that were nearing expiry.  Heck, I have chicken sitting in the fridge defrosting that I need to bake tonight, what do I do?  Throw the chicken in the oven and quickly drive to Sultan's to pick up dinner.  The Chicken can be lunch and dinner for tomorrow.   First time at Sultan's so I wasn't sure of what to expect.  It's just like your usual fast food joint/cafeteria except it's middle eastern.  I had to use the groupons so I made sure I got enough so that I wouldn't be missing out on the deal that they were providing.  The guys were pretty helpful in explaining what the items were.   I ordered to go.  Some lamb shwarma, hold the hummus on one, spicy for the other.  The tilapia dinner and some dolmades.  Dolmades tasted like the ones from a can that we get from the Greek grocery store.  The tilapia was very interesting, pretty good flavor.  The shwarma was also interesting.    I've had really good middle eastern food and I'm not so sure that this was reaaaaaaaaaally good.   It was fresh, tasty and overall decent.   I'd go back again some day in the future.

Those 2 stars are for the salad bar. I went because of a groupon coupon and I was very disappointed. The falafel is big, but bland and came without tahini - what is that? The Baba Ghanoush was missing the tahini also, so tasted more like blah eggplant salad. And the Jerusalem Salad is a watery mess with tasteless dried mint and a ton of cucumber seeds. All this says to me that they don't care enough about quality or taste or taking the extra time to prep food properly.  With all due respect to those who love this place, I advise others to find the Pita Cafe or any of the places around Kedzie and Lawrence.

Still very good, but not as fresh. I felt that the food was reheated instead of fresh. It is a smaller outpost with only 2 guys working, which I can understand. Still very cheap and good considering it is located in Lincoln Park.

Their chicken shwarma sandwich is so good!  Not only  is this place cheap and fast but the portions are huge!  I eat half the sandwich for lunch and eat the leftover for dinner.  The yogurt sauce they put in the sandwich is really smooth and melts in yo mouf!

Maybe I should have had the falafel.    Then maybe I could have found something good to eat at this place.   Truly disappointed in the food....meat combo (did not taste fresh/lacked flavor), lentil soup (again where is the flavor)...service was good that is why I gave this place one star.   The food is zero stars.

As far as I'm concerned, this is the greatest falafel in Chicago. I eat the falafel sandwich at least once ca week. And usually the lentil soup rounds out the meal. Really really highly recommended. Go humus!!

Cheap, filling and super tasty. There's not much more to say about this place. I loves me some cheap ethnic food, and this place hits the spot. I get a chicken shawerma every. single. week from this place and love it every time. The guys are really nice and fill that pita with hummus, jerusalem salad, and meat, so much that you might have to save a little bit for later. And its only $5!!!  For drinking you have san pellegrino and IBC root beer (which goes shockingly well with Middle Eastern food).  They have a really nice salad bar and tons of Arabic snacks lying around as well, but I have yet to take the plunge. There is also a nice little seating area with tables for two. I would imagine you could have a great date here! (ba dum chhh)  Thank you, I'll be here all week.

This place was a great find after getting back from Europe and missing doner kebabs at every corner.  It's not quite the same, but it's as close as I've seen in the area.  It's certainly affordable ($5-6 for a shawerma that will fill you up), very quick (almost fast food like), and is pretty good overall.

Cheap and healthy! I rediscovered Sultans this weekend when I was looking for something that would satisfy my ever-complicated criteria for a healthy and satisfying lunch. I had a large lentil soup which hit the spot (needed just a couple shakes of salt) and was only $3. A small soup is only $2. Hallelujah! I lurve soup...I would eat it everyday if I could. I also assembled a little plate from the delightful salad bar. On it there are ginomorous marinated artichoke hearts, kalamata olives, stuffed grape leaves, big hunks of feta cheese, grated beets...all in addition to lettuces and other standard salad bar components. Everything was fresh, and at $5.99 a pound, very reasonable.  All together my lunch cost me $5 and some change. I left full and happy.  Now that's what I call a super value meal. P.S. Sultan's if you had a  River North location I would be all over you for weekday lunch.
A middle eastern place that has sirachia?!?! AMAZING!  The food was delicious and very filling.  A great place to pickup a cheap & yummy lunch!

Love the falafel and hummus here.  I honestly haven't had much else, but you can go in and get some hummus and pita for quite cheap.   Service is quick, but the place isn't huge, so dining in with just a couple people can get tough when it's somewhat busy inside.

I love Sultans! They mark on the menu whether each items is Vegan...and there are a lot of options! I love the falafel pita sandwich, the veggie combo, the hummus (love their hummus!), etc. This is one of the usual places I eat at; although, I must say I'm partial to the Wicker Park location.

I'd heard Sultan's has the best falafel in Chicago, and I can't categorically deny that (because I haven't had too much falafel in Chicago), but I can definitely say that the falafel here was okay, but not great. It's definitely not the best falafel I'VE ever had (that title belongs to Mim's Cafe in St. Paul), and there were serious issues with the preparation here that give me pause. Food aside, the Clark Street branch of Sultan's is extremely small and has space for maybe eight people, all crammed near the entrance. This is a place where you get take-out. Conveniently, all vegan items are clearly marked on the wall menu. I had a falafel sandwich ($4.14 with tax) which is hastily slapped together from already-prepared ingredients, much like a Subway sandwich or a Chipotle burrito. My biggest gripe was with the temperature of the food---the falafel pieces were lukewarm, the pita was room temperature and the tahini-cucumber sauce was cold, creating a passable, but inelegant whole. At the very least, the falafel needs to be hot, and the rest can be at room temperature, but if you have any cold items in the mix, the sandwich gets all messed up. I did like the portion size, which was big enough for a meal, but also quick and cheap. This is the ideal snack or light dinner food. I also liked the hot peppers tossed in, which added a significant level of spice (albeit one that wasn't evenly distributed, because everything was slapped together, rather than mixed properly). Next time I'll try the original Sultan's to see if there's any difference in quality. On a whole, I give this place three stars because it's quick and cheap, but the food has room for improvement, and I have to believe there's better falafel somewhere else in Chicago. If not, then it's pretty pathetic if Sultan's is the best Chicago can do.

Shortest review I'll ever write. One plump, delicious falafel sandwich + a can of Diet Coke is $5. Sultan's, you've won my heart! Fast, inexpensive and they deliver. Oh, and there's a little salad bar with tons of fresh goodies if you're trying to avoid the fried falafel. I say... good luck with that!

I came to this place for dinner one night. It was close to the Arlington house hostel nearby and I was just looking for something tasty to eat on Clark street. Initially, I was heading to the deli but saw this place and immediately developed a craving for a lamb shawarma. I got it in a pita to go and snarfed it down back at the hostel. It was very good! If I had stayed longer, I bet I would have returned for another one.

I've been working around Clark and Deming this week and have been itching to try out these places since walking by them on Monday. I finally checked out Sultan's Market for lunch and I am a fan. I'm not a Middle Eastern connoisseur, but I liked what I had and it was fast, which was key because I was in a hurry. I tried the Chicken Shawarma pita (spicy), and the cucumber they put in the pita was delicious. The hummus base was also pretty tasty. It wasn't particularly spicy, but I never expect Middle Eastern food to be too hot. The chicken was flavorful, but perhaps a bit on the dry side. This is definitely more of a take-out on-the-go type of place, and the speed at which they serve you is nice. I didn't notice any drinks on the menu, but I was in a hurry so I might have missed it. Next time I stop in, I will check out all the neat stuff they have on sale (their "market goods").

Sultans market was an okay middle eastern restaurant. It had pretty good food but nothing amazing. The place is small and there's not a lot of available seating. Sultans was somewhat authentic and it was good, but I wouldn't go out of my way to go here.
Love place! Cheap prices for decent portions. Vegan items are marked with a v!

I don't like onions. Hummus looks like something my cat would... ya know. Falafel... falaf-what? Jerusalem salad... is it holy? Chicken and pita... ok that's delicious. Why am I giving 3 stars, or any, to a restaurant that serves food full of ingredients I don't enjoy eating?  Call me crazy, but I actually took a chance on a chicken shawerma pita last week and found it to be quite good.  Somehow the combination of pita, chicken, hummus, jerusalem salad sans onions and some spicy sauce turned into a combination I thought was excellent.  I will admit, I cringed when I saw the massive glob of hummus the guy put in my pita as he went down the line (next time I'll tell him to go easy on it)... however, combined with everything else (props to the chicken which was excellent) it hit the spot. Aside from that, the service was quick and the staff were friendly.  My shawerma was only $4.75 I believe, and was more than enough for a meal. I'll definitely be back, and maybe next time I'll be a bit more daring and go for the lamb... if that's just as good, I could see another star - maybe two - for this place.

When I want some cheap eats on that block and I'm not in the mood for Aloha Eats,  Sultan's is my alternative.  Not the best falafel I have had.  But when you mix in the fresh veg and sauce, it makes for a tasty treat.
Not much to add, it's Mediterranean fast food. It's cheap, tasty, and filling. Good selection so you don't get bored. I just moved out of this neighborhood so I'm sad I won't get to eat this as much.

I know yelpers rave about the falafel at Sultan's but in my two visits here, I wasn't too impressed.The falafel is decent but it's not what it's supposed to be: crunchy and flavorful! Try  Taza (in the loop) and Pita Inn (in skokie) for much better (and usually fresher) falafel.

Small place but the food is awesome and reasonably priced.  Chicken and lamb shawarma were both solid -- and the Meat Combo dinner is only $8 for a decent amount of food.  The falafel sandwich was pretty big and not dry at all.  The only thing is that it can get packed and there isn't much room, but it's worth it.
The perfect falafel. Cheap delicious hot spicy fresh crisp crunchy creamy AWESOME

Not as big as the North Ave location but in now way lesser in quality. I think i actually prefer that I can get in and out with easy for a tasty falafel sandwich in a hurry.  The staff is always nice and quick with your meal.  Everything I have had there has been excellent.

If I could afford it, I'd eat here every day. WAIT, I CAN afford it! My falafel sandwich and can of diet coke only cost me $5! This is the stuff that dreams are made of... Salad bar, good. Falafel, good. Hummus, good. The chicken shawarma sandwich I had wasn't *as* good as the falafel, but it was still pretty darn good.  Also, don't let the small, crowded space deter you -- it's almost always crowded when I go, but the line moves quickly and the tables always seem to open up in time for me to sit and enjoy my lunch.

Not terrible, not fantastic. The chicken shawarma was dry and felt overstuffed with mediocre veggies. Worst of all, the chicken was so fatty I had to pluck it out and eat around it. The hummus was bland but decent. I could really go for some more pita bread with it. Honestly, people. I am not capable of stuffing that much hummus onto one little pita in order to consume it. If I'm desperate for Middle Eastern cuisine and in Lincoln Park, I'll go here. Otherwise, I'm ready to let go of this location in favor of the North Ave. alternative, or even better: I'll stick with Taste of Lebanon in Andersonville for real cheap authentic Middle Eastern cuisine sans fatty meat.

After researching restaurants to try for my first trip to Chicago I came across over 400 reviews on the amazing falafel at Sultan's market. I couldn't get it out of my head, I just had to try those delicious falafel balls. My friend and I ventured to the Lincoln Park location and tried a falafel sandwich, a lamb shawarma sandwich, a spinach pie, and grape leaves. The lamb shawarma was delicious, and while the falafel was good, it was not great, and certainly not the best. I've had better in Phoenix, and that's not saying much. The grape leaves were good, but the most disappointment came from the spinach pie. It wasn't made with phylo dough and didn't have any feta cheese. It was made with a very hard dough and wasn't good. The place itself is also not a market, I was hoping to find little Middle Eastern chocolates and candy, but instead I left feeling disappointed. If you do decide to eat here, do yourself a favor; order the the lamb shawarma, stay away from the spinach pie, and order the falafel (just to get it out of your system) but don't set your expectations too high.

In a hurry? Trying to beat a hangover? On a budget? Trying to stick to a healthy diet? Sultan's Market is probably the way to go if you answered yes to any or all of those questions. The soups taste exactly like how your mom's would , if your mom was middle eastern and told you to shut up and eat what was in front of you. You know you would gladly oblige because it hits the spot after a long day or night of shenanigans.  The Shawrma can be a little dry if you get there towards the end of their day but get there any sooner all day long and you'll be pleasantly surprised with some fresh, juicy and spiced just right meat. Lamb or chicken, they've got the recipe down and aim to please.  They're not the fanciest dive on the block, but the tin tiles on the wall and aromatic flavors in the air will give you a taste of the desert once you walk in. If you're in the area, and looking to venture away from the abundance of sushi you can find , then there really is no reason why you shouldn't stop in for a quick bite.

THEY DELIVER!! AWESOME lamb shawerma is amazing .  i discovered shawerma sandwiches while living in London, and although I have yet to find a shawerma that comes close to the ones i had abroad,  this one is damn good. highly recommend
I'm tired of getting what can only be described a second rate Sultan's.  This location just plain sucks compared to the one on North Ave.

Went for the first time this weekend and it was great for a quick (somewhat healthy) lunch. Had the lamb shawarma plate which comes with rice, tabouleh an hummus. Everything was very tasty and only $7. The food wasn't as goos as Old Jerusalem, but it was quick and tasy!

HOME OF THE McSHAWARMA It's fast. It's cheap. It's filling. It's adequate, but not stellar. In short, Sultan's market is the McDonalds of middle eastern food.   The shawarma is often dry, the Jerusalem salad a little watery, the hummus on par with store-bought varieties, and the staff indifferent to your presence.  That said, it's still a good deal.

Finally went to this place.  Pretty good.  Not the best felafel I've had but pretty good.  My Wife loved the salad bar.  Everything was a good value for the money.  And they have my favorite drink pairing for felafel:  Vimto.  Yea, i know it tastes like cough syrup. The decor is real nice.  They seem to have a good amount of room for people to sit and eat and not be in the way of the line.  They also sell some stuff like oils and spices and things here. Will be back.

I'm being a bit generous here, but I also haven't tried the falafel. I've only had their chicken shawarma, which was pretty good. For the location of this place, the prices are great. And I definitely felt full after my sandwich.  The only problem is, once you've had Pita Inn, you can't really settle for much else. But since I'm not in Skokie and/or Glenview everyday, I can go for some Sultan's every now and then.

I had heightened expectations of this place. I keep trying to find a middle eastern restaurant that hits all the right notes. From reading the reviews and seeing the popularity of this place, I could not wait to try it!  I went and picked up lunch to go for a friend and I. The store is tiny but very cute. The service is awesome, so friendly! Plus, the prices can't be beat. I ordered three dinner combos - lamb shawerma, chicken shawerma, and the kefta kabob. Each came with your choice of curry rice or lentil rice, and salad and hummus. I got the curry rice and Jerusalem salad for all three meals. $6 a piece! I figured this was going to be a new regular spot for me. The food was good. Nothing spectacular. The meats were flavorful but too dry for my taste. The highlight was the hummus and the salad. The salad was perfectly flavored and very refreshing, the hummus is just the right consistency.  I'd go back but its not something I'd crave and go out of my way to get. I'll keep searching for a good authentic middle eastern place.

sooooooooo yummy.  sooooo cheap.  sooooooo fast.  sooooo much food. I got the falafel sandwich, spicy!  The falafel was good.  I've had some that were slightly more delicious, but it's the sandwich that makes this place stand out.  On a falafel sandwich you get hummus, spicy sauce, tabouleh, veggies, and a delicious humangous pita.  I could come here daily.  Perhaps i will....

It was a slow, incremental and calculated mission by my girlfriend to wean me off of an Italian beef/pizza diet (if you let her tell it.)  But now she can proudly stand on the deck of a Navy ship in a camouflaged flight suit under a "Mission Accomplished".  I like hummus & falafels. These were decent, but not the best I've ever had. What was excellent was my experience at Sultan's. It's a teeny tiny place that manages to be little without being intimate that for some reason attracts a lot of cyclists. The food is quick and pretty cheap thanks greatly to a Groupon promo. Yeah! Late Friday night as my group dined, the guys behind the counter threw on some techno beats that ate up the space. Nice, odd touch.

I'll begin by saying that I'm a fallafel virgin. Never had the awesomeness that is fallafel until now. Today is a day that will change my eating habits FOREVER.  I bought a $15 Groupon for Sultans for $5 and I'm so glad that I did. I can't believe that I've gone my whole life without falafel. It's ludicris (and not in a cool way like the singer). My sis and I came in for lunch today and had Spinach pie - eh, could have been better. There wasn't much flavor to it, but it was quite large Meat Pie- LOVED this. I wish it had been bigger. I could have eaten 10 of them. I have no idea what type of meat it was, but it was faaaab! Large Lentil Soup- I've also never had lentil soup, but it was delicious (after adding a touch of salt) and really great mixed with any of the other foods I ordered. Fallafel Sandwich- I ordered it medium with cucumber salad on top and boy oh boy, it was so crunchy, tender, juicy, flavorful and just perfect in every way. I can't wait to eat more of them! Lentils with rice- This was much better and more flavorful than I had imagined it would be. It went so well with the lentil soup over it. All in all, we had a tom of food (all of the above) plus a large bottle of San Peligrino for about $18.  Food this good at this price?? I'll be back at least once a week.

One of the best cheapest meals you'll probably find in the area and the food is pretty decent for the money, but best falafel ever? Uh, no....you guys need to eat more falafels or something. The falafels here are too large and kind of dry and taste like they have been sitting under a warming lamp (because they have) instead of being freshly fried.  I'd skip them altogether next time and just go for some shwarma and the lovely salad bar. (but the shwarma is dry too, because it isn't cut off of meat on a spit when you order, instead it's in like a warming dish or something like that for a while) The salad bar is really beautiful.  Marinated shrimp with squid(?), rice-stuffed grape leaves, sun dried tomatoes, great veggies and a few things that I don't even know what they were for $5.99 a pound.  That with the decent shwarma and the decent hummus smothering the dry other stuff made for a right decent meal. PS - this place has really, really, really, really, really, really tiny and cramped seating.

I've suckled at the teat of Sultan's salad bar for years now.  I mean, come on, it's pretty much the cheapest salad bar around, and has tons of stuff that you won't find at Dominicks or your other plain Jane lettuce smorgasbords.   I can usually be found causing a ruckus at the other location, and had never been to this one which is like a mousehole in the wall of the Damen joint.  It is TINY.  I filled my tiny salad tin with beautiful balls of fresh mozzarella.  They also had the pita chips that aren't often gracing the bins of the Wicker Park bar.  I'm sad to say, the tomatoes were pretty weak though.  I hope this changes soon.   Chicken shawarma pita was good as always, and my gal pal loved her falafel and odd concoction of salad goodness.   I'd maybe come back to this one for take-out if I were in the area, but it's just too tight of a squeeze for dining in.

AMAZING falaffel!  I love this place.  Its so freaking cheap.  Not to mention fast.  Falaffel sandwich is great and they even have a choice of mild, medium, SPICY!  Plus, they have a great little salad bar.  I love this place for a cheap, quick bite!  Definitely have to try it if you havent already

Sultan's Market is 2 miles from my house. (1.99 to be exact. I mapquested it.) And it was a lovely afternoon so we walked. And if you do the math that's four miles (3.98. I wonder if there's a way to get them to count my front stairs) So that's why we had to use two fifteen-dollar groupons for two people - That and the fact that I wanted everything. We shared the egg and cheese bread, the zatter bread, the spinach cheese pie, and some rice and lentils with jerusalem salad, and some baba ghanooj with pita. Then I had a falafel sandwich, the fella had a lamb shawerma pita and a smattering of the salad bar. The grand total after our thirty dollars in ultimate savings? $1.29 In unrelated news the Austrian Bakery is next door and there's a cool empanada-only place across the street. It's probably only 1.95 miles from my house so I'll eat a little lighter. Or fill my pockets on the way to the zoo sometime.

Finally tried Sultan's Market a couple weeks ago with friend Alayna H. after passing it by for so long. It's a Pretty small place with limited seating. I Had the Falafel Sandwich which was pretty damn good and a side of Curry Rice. Had some good baklava and a can of San Pellagrino Aranciata. Really good and cheap, but Quality eats here. I Will definitely be back.

I'm sorry, but anyone who thinks their shawarma, falafel or really anything, is the "best" in the city needs to get their ass out of Lincoln Park and check out some actual middle eastern food up on the Northwest side...or hell, go to Pita Inn in the burbs...even that place has it together SO much more than this joint. Let's see....where do I begin? 1. The falafel are WAY too big. The smaller the ball, the better the filling-to-crispy-outside ratio. You want that. Consistently dry, probably because I have never seen them actually make the falafel, just leave in under a heat lamp. 2. Their shawarma is kept in warming drawers! WHAT THE FUCK ARE YOU PEOPLE THINKING?? The whole point of skewered meats is that they roast on the spit and are sliced off, in all their juicy goodness, to order. A warming drawer just dries out the meat and defeats the whole point of spit roasting them in the first place.  3. Almost nothing is made in house. Dolmas? Nope. Baklava? Nope. Meat and spinach pies? Nope. Hummus? Not sure...but I would venture a big ol' NOPE.  Is anything here absolutely horrendous? No, but a little effort and some homemade love might make the food worth eating. There is so much great Middle Eastern food in Chicago, this level of quality should not be tolerated. 4. Lastly, with the exception of the middle-eastern guy with the stubble beard, all the other employees are assholes. I have never received a smile when I walked in or any sort of pleasant service. The dudes throwing together my piss-poor sandwich act like they are doing me a favor...Never get a "Thank You". If you eat in, you never get asked how things were. It is as if running the restaurant is a chore that no one wants to do. This is precisely why I left Lincoln Park. All these people that absolutely love this place don't have a clue and just fall into the cookie-cutter franchised mediocrity that the Lincoln Park food scene is quickly turning into. Ah....I feel better....

Now that I work in Lincoln Park I am trying out all of the places I've been wanting to try in the neighborhood.  Sultans is perfect because it is a few doors down, quick and yummy. Theirs is some of the best falafel I have ever eaten.  The sandwich is a pocket of tastiness.  And cheap!  Yay! And can I tell you?  The guys working in there are so nice.  Very friendly. I have been drooling (not literally, ew, gross) over the salad bar and will try it next time.

I'm ashamed to say I haven't really explored all the city has to offer when it comes to Middle Eastern food...So I purchased the $15 for $5 Groupon for Sultan's and headed to Lincoln Park with a friend to try it out.   I got the Veggie Platter which comes with falafel, choice of rice, choice of salad, pita and hummus...all for about $6, great deal!  The food was delcious, hummus was slightly more grainy than I'm used to, but still good.  My friend got the falafel sandwich and was very pleased as well. We also got a little package of baklava for $5, I thought it was an okay deal until we opened it up and realized there were TWO layers in there...which made it a steal of a deal! Overall delicious food, and I will definitely be going back...most likely to the North Ave location since that's closer to my hood.   Not sure but when we went they said Cash only...?  Maybe we were under the credit card minimum since we had the Groupon.  Also, not a lot of seating space understandably, so be prepared to eat it somewhere else if necessary.

I love the falafel here.  It's big and tasty, and I always like falafel that is more green than brown.  I've eaten things off the salad bar, too, and that has always been good, but I have a hard time ordering anything besides the falafel.

I heard the food is good, but I wouldn't know, since they pack up all the food a mommy freaking hour and a half before closing time.  Go there at like 5 pm; maybe they won't have put the lamb shwerma away.

Sultan's Market is my surrogate for Pita Inn. I really like it, but it still can't quite compare. That being said, the salad bar is great, and I have never in my life had such amazing grape leaves (that's the one thing they've got on Pita Inn). I also really like that they add tabbouleh and hummus to the falafel sandwich, 'tho the hummus and baba ganoush aren't as smooth or thick as I would like. Anyway, definitely worth stopping by, even if it will always live in Pita Inn's shadow.

My fave of the two Sultan's locations, for their proximity to me and their acceptance of credit cards for payment. And, of course, the best and least expensive falafel sandwiches in Chicago. On the service side, they're always nice and professional, if not overly outgoing and friendly. Last year on July 4th, however, I stopped in for a bite around 3pm and the place was deserted. They were about to close up many hours early due to slow business, and gave me some free soup, rice, and Jerusalem salad with my falafel sandwich (they were going to toss it all). I was full for the whole day, and am even more a fan of them than I was before.

We always end up with the chicken schwerma and falafel sandwich.  I really like their hummus.  Sultan's is really cheap and you can sit on the patio in the summer.  The guys working there have always been quick and courteous.  The salad bar is kind of jammed in the corner, but it really works out pretty well.  I haven't tried anything on it yet (mostly because I love the chicken too much) but almost everything on it looks fresh and good.  They even sell a few grocery staples, such as mixes and sauces.
chicken is awesome and this place is cheap! the guys are nice and let me do half curry and half lentil rice and the salads the same way. BEST falafel I've ever had

Just moved to the area and was craving some Middle Eastern food like I used to get at the Egyptian place down the street from me in Astoria.  Well, stumbled upon Sutlan's Market and figured I'd go in.  The lamb was a dry, but their chicken was amazing.  And the falafel was the best i've found.  Plus you can buy siracha by the bottle full there. I'll definitely be back.

I know it's almost sacrilege in this community to say that I had never been to a Sultan's Market but until this past weekend that was the case.  On the recommendation of Jerry M, both from her ROtD and suggestion for our lunch, I finally got the chance to dine here and realized what I had been missing! While seating is a bit tight I had a great meal of a spicy falafel sandwich (with no cucumbers). It was great; crispy falafel, soft pita and smooth hummus (although I ordered a chicken schwarama, and got falafel instead it was so good that I did not complain).   What surprised me most was the amazing salad bar for $2 less per pound that the Whole Foods one, with which I am so in love. In addition to normal salad fixings there were dolmas, brussel sprouts, sun-dried tomatoes, lots of cheese choices and fun ethnic items.  There is a good chance that the Whole Foods salad bar has just lost my loyalty to this cheaper and more extensively stocked salad bar!

If I'm looking for something a little different on my lunch break I'll head over to Sultan's. I love the chicken shawarma. It is really filling and cheap enough that I can grab myself a can of coke and still not feel guilty that I didn't pack myself a ham sandwich for lunch.

Sultan's market has good hummus and falafel. And their prices are pretty decent. However, I do not find myself craving it as much as some other places in town. It is pretty basic. It does have a great location, but if this restaurant was in some random neighborhood, I wonder how many people would talk about how great the food is. Perception I guess.
A vegan paradise. Amazing food, friendly staff, affordable prices.

OH MY STARS!!! (As my coworker would say...)  I almost went to the new Nesh Mediterranean Grill on Fullerton but was urged to change my plan of attack by all the positive Yelp feedback on Sultan's Market. While I'm a tough cookie to crumble, this place became the Cookie Monster--it instantly devoured my doubts of visiting a walk-up "buffet-style" joint with few seats.  The decor was very cute, colorful, and had a gorgeous painted, tin ceiling.  [Although I'm not sure what all the nails were from in the one wall, but my eyes caught the food items before I had time to further investigate.] All of their choices seemed delicious and very reasonably priced (roughly $7 for a full dinner--which you'll probably have left overs from).  Their falafels are out of this world (well at least out of this country, but probably found identical to those of the Middle East)!!  The chicken kabob is crispy and tender.  I loved their Kefta too which was perfectly spiced but not overpowering.  They have options for everyone--even spinach, meat, and egg & cheese pies! The other 4 buddies of mine who came with me moaned over the tastes which we all tried to savor.  One in particular threw his scarf around his neck and shouted  "Good Stuff" as we all exited before him.  Yes, it truly was!  If you're on the run and looking for great grub, definitely stop by Sultan's! Oh and girls, if you're into punk/skater kinda guys, there may also be eye candy present too!

At 11:00pm your dinner choices are going to be a bit limiting. I am talking just arrived in a city, starving, and need more then a mini-plane beverage and a pack of pretzels. We were in the LP area and after many failed attempts at trying to find a sushi place we settled for take away from Sultan's.  The veggie combo, is large, cheap and okay. The tabbouleh was alright, the hummus was not great, but the lentil rice was a winner. No serious complaints for a late night dinner that cost $7.

Cheap. Fast. Damn good.  I've never had a bad experience at Sultan's.  I can eat it every day.  Nearly everything on the menu is flavored well.  The only problem I have is picking out one thing every time I walk in.

**Sigh** Oh how I miss living  just steps from Sultan's.  The food is fresh and delicious.  Service is fast and prices are CHEAP.  There's even a little salad bar with all kinds of goodies that you can get to-go.  Lots of great beverage choices and even some imported cookies and candies.

Yes, this place is worth the walk from my work. I used to settle on Pita Pit for my falafel pita fix, but they charge extra for everything. I get a super-filling pita for under 5 bucks tax included? Yeah, buddy! Sultan's also carries Vegan Decadence Cappuccino cookies (great treat to share!).

the falafel here is great, always crisp, not soggy or greasy. i especially like the falafel sandwich, spicy, with feta cheese on it. although they only toss 2 chopped falafel balls into the pita it is very filling.  the hummus is yummy and the balance of everything in the sandwich (falafel, rooster hot sauce, hummus, falafel, cucumber salad, feta) is always proportional.  husband ordered the chicken soup since he thinks he's coming down with something and he thoroughly enjoyed it.  i stole a taste and it was delicious with LARGE chunks of real chicken, good sized veggies, and delicious broth that is not too salty.   sultan's is consistent, has friendly employees, and is cheap.  can't really ask for more.  actually, the salad bar also looks amazing and i noticed it had kimchee in it today.  showing some love for the koreans :)  wish i still lived down the street.

Here's my deal with sultan's - it seems like the McDonald's of Middle Eastern food.  Er, if McDonald's was palatable.  It just seems kinda generic.  It's hard to really screw up falafel, rice, lentils, etc., but when it's good, you know and you crave it.  I don't crave Sultan's, and I'm never particularly wowed by their food.  I go there because it's convenient.   Bottom line, I wouldn't hesitate to go there, but I also wouldn't miss it if it shut down tomorrow.

I'm on a meat sabbatical. I also love hamburgers. That love is the stuff legends are made of. Wait, I'm on a meat sabbatical. Crap. The falafel sandwiches here have been a godsend for my bloody red meat cravings. And a bit easier on my wallet as well. But not my waistline. Let's just say that I've been craving hamburgers alot this past month. I guess it's time to break out the winter jeans. Or run 3 miles instead of 2 at the gym. The lentil soup isn't bad either - make sure they give you a lemon slice with it. Delish! The seating area is tiny. But I've always gotten a seat. But I like to sit outside. Tiny patio outside as well. There's a tiny theme here. But not on my waistline, nor portion sizes as well. I'm still on a meat sabbatical. Yay for falafel!

Yummy, yummy in my tummy! For a vegetarian on a budget this place is a dream come true! I can't believe I haven't tried Sultan's sooner, especially since it got high marks from a friend, a fellow picky vegetarian. As an added bonus it's within walking distance of my house. I highly recommend the falafel here. I should note that after my 911 rolls at Sushi O Sushi the other night I was a little gun shy and got my falafel with medium spice. In hindsight, I should've gotten it with regular spice and on the side; since the pita's are deep, there wasn't enough spicy sauce to cover my falafel. However, I was so hungry I didn't want to interrupt my nosh to ask for more. I can't wait to come back here, I'll be trying out the Zetter Fettia and taking home some hummus and tabbouleh too. They have a bunch of vegetarian and vegan options plus the salad bar has something like 30 different ingredient options. Don't worry, if you're a meat eater, there are plenty of options for you here too. The place is small, I think it seats about 10-12 people tops; I would imagine it's busy during peak hours, but you can carry out and order for delivery too. Bottom line: I got an awesome falafel that filled me up for under $4.25. I will definitely be going back, a lot.

The guy that took my order was cold but at least the guys that made my food behind the counter was not. Eat your shawarmas right away!! They slab on a hearty portion of hummus so if you take your time, your pita will be a soggy mess. I thought my one shawarma was pretty filling for dinner. The chicken pieces were tender and savory but I didn't like the random non-meat chicken pieces here and there. Just my preference but I like skinless and there were a couple of clumpy tendon-y pieces that I just couldn't masticate. It was pretty gross to extract it from my mouth and into a discrete piece of throwaway napkin.

Good place for cheap eats, it's a fast casual restaurant so you just order your food and sit down. For a cheap bastard like me that's a good thing when eating in Chicago. I ordered the sampler platter for 7 dollars which was probably the most expensive thing on the menu. It also had the added benefit of being extremely close to my hotel (Days Inn). Seating is pretty sparse and it got a little cramped during lunch time, I had to move over a chair to accommodate other people. While it wasn't the best Mediterranean food i've eaten, I think i'm spoiled by living near Dearborn, Michigan which has over a quarter of Arab Americans residing there.

I have been at Sultan's once and I am not planning to come back. I don't know, I might have ordered the wrong thing, but my chicken with rice and something else tasted terrible!  Should have gone to Chipotle instead!

Whoa, hey, this place is tasty! I was always weary of going here, because my taste buds are naturally inclined to the cheese, meat and bakery fare next door at the Austrian Bakery.  After a super long night of work, I come home to my dining options on Clark Stpizza, Chinese, Mexican, cupcakes, crepes and overpriced salads. Then! I spot this little Mediterranean oasis and was pleasantly surprised that it was pretty darn good, authentic tasting and CHEAP. Only $8 for the mixed dinner plate with a heap of hummus and great cucumber salad.  Food: 4 Stars  Service: 1 Star  To the dreaded dudeman that was serving my food, please don't eat while serving my food. I don't appreciate the prospect of your spittle from whateverinthehell it was you were eating to land up in my baba ganoush! Your co-worker picking a broken fork out of the cash drawer and you replying with That's my toothpick. was just plain wrong. You looked pretty stoned, and that's okay, but that doesn't excuse you from being disgusting.

Whoa, hey, this place is tasty! I was always weary of going here, because my taste buds are naturally inclined to the "cheese, meat and bakery" fare next door at the Austrian Bakery.  After a super long night of work, I come home to my dining options on Clark St...pizza, Chinese, Mexican, cupcakes, crepes and overpriced salads. Then! Your co-worker picking a broken fork out of the cash drawer and you replying with "That's my toothpick." was just plain wrong. You looked pretty stoned, and that's okay, but that doesn't excuse you from being disgusting.

Came here for a late night meal after drinking around the area.  My bf got the lamb shwarma, OK, not great.  The price was around $6.  Then I got the egg and cheese pie for $2, that was OK as well.  Def.  a good option for a midnight snack.

people have raved about the place that i'm certain we just went on a bad day?... the hummus was tasteless and too watery.  the baba ganoush - some of the best i've had but still could've been a little thicker so the goodness wouldn't run off my pita!  husband got the beef shwarma that he said was pretty good but not the right temperature.  i think that's the problem - everything is served cafeteria style there that textures, flavor and correct temperature are lost.   despite the prep, the service is still slow.  i think the guy behind the counter was just... a little... well..."relaxed".  we failed to try the falafel so can't comment on that.  NOTHING will ever beat pita inn... i dare someone to prove me wrong.  pita inn please make your way to the city!!

Great place for cheap eats.  First, the salad bar is excellent.  The selection is extremely generous (including shrimp, chicken, dolmeh, calamari rings, feta, olives, green beans and all the regular salad fixings).  The falafal is great and if you order the sandwich, the put a nice swipe of hummus inside the pita - yummy.  The biggest downside is their shawarma, which is frequently pre-cut, can get a bit dry.

One of those places that you could easily miss walking down the street amidst the tons of restaurants and shops on Clark Street, but definitely worth the stop! The chicken shawarma sandwich (also filled with hummus) is one of the best I've had. You can get it mild to spicy on request, and it's a cheap filling meal for only about $5. The tabouli and hummus are great sides too. This location is much cleaner and nicer than the Wicker Park one, but also much smaller so I always get take out.  It probably has a little to do with the different character of the neighborhoods too - the Wicker Park location definitely fits appropriately with the atmosphere of that neighborhood and is a little more authentic than this location. Regardless, I am very happy to live so close to Sultan's in Lincoln Park!

Sultan's Market, in the LP, what?!  Yup, my old friends at Sultan's Wicker Park spawned a little offspring right on Clark.  Same great service, and same great food.  This location is smaller however, with seating for only about 10 people. The shawerma was tasty and spicy (or so I was told), and my lentil soup was delicious!  Just what I needed for the nasty cold my beloved city bestowed upon me during my recent visit.  I also forgot how generous they are with their hummus portions and pita.  Great little place if you're craving some quick mediterranean in the LP.

I thought I ordered chicken shawarma - I ended up getting dried up crusty cold chicken jerky on top of rice. Maybe the not so friendly guy has bad hearing. Who knows. What I do know is I did not like it, I did not like it at all.

Ahhh the Sultan of all Markets  Every time I pass by I have the inclination to stop in for some falafel and Jerusalem salad - even if I have just eaten. SM has great, fresh, food for a cost effective price. I love to grab some to-go items and take them to be park and read - its a great picnic stop on the way to the LP zoo or Botanical Garden. The salad bar is wondermous, the staff is always friendly and are always patient with me (as I am horribly indecisive sometimes) Gotta try if you are in the area - or near the wicker park outlet. mmmm chick peas

It's cheap and it's good but it's decidedly sub-par to the original Sultan's on North Ave. The kids who work there are kind of dicky and they prepare the food differently-- half the time they don't chop up the falafel to go in the sandwich, just stick two falafel balls into the pita and call it a day.
Quality grub that's quick and cheap.  I'm so glad this place is on my block.     Grab a kefta sandwich and a falafel or two and you'll be a happy camper.

so good. soooooooooooo good. it doesn't help that sultan's is on my way to and from work. as a result, they see a lot of me. $4.15 = huge and deliciously fresh falafel sandwich. lots of tasty food without completely emptying my wallet, which makes me a happy camper.

So a friend has been telling me to go eat here and I finally got a chance to today as I got off work early.  I'm gonna make this short and sweet: For $5.24 I got a falafel sandwich and a coke.  I left very satisfied and with a full belly.  The falafel was yummy, cucumber salad kept each bite refreshing, hummus had a nice flavor and to top it off, they use my favorite hot sauce, Sriracha (the Thai rooster sauce).  It was super YUM and I'll be back, especially since they are open late.
Sooo good, and affordable.  The Baked Egg Fattia is my fave and I can never pass up the Zatter bread.  Probably my fave take-out place so far!

Id give this place ten stars if I could!!I LOVE SULTAN's Market!!!!!!!!!!! The food is perfect. Huge portions for cheap, flavorful Mediterranean.  Personally I like the Lincoln Park location better, but only because it is   less crowded due to seating restraints. The Wicker Park one is equally WONDERFUL in quality/atmosphere though.

I hate that I can't give a place 5 stars.  Not that this place wouldn't deserve the extra one, but for 5 stars and that special red color you get when someone commits on that 5th - I guess we really have to share a special moment. Not that Sultanas doesn't make me happy.  Good falafel sandweech.  The lentil soup is always just warm when I get it, but it's really good so I don't care.  There self-service bar is sweet.  The dolmades always look so tempting as I walk by. Okay, so I may have picked one up with my grimy fingers and shoved it in my mouth on the way to place my order.  I mean, they're always right there, at the end of the bar, really inconspicuous-like, ready to be plucked. Cash only, which is kind of lame, but they have an Automated Teller Machine, which dispenses dollars for you to pay with when you need some. The last time I was there, I got the vegetarian combo.  Came with hummus (awesome), baba, rice, tabouli, jerusalem salad, falafel, and some serious pita.  I know, not hard to screw up, but it all tastes good...and fresh. I like the decor on the inside - cool, antique-ey with lots of tiles (Wicker Park one).  I know, it's hipster-ish, but whatever.  I may be a closet one.  Also seems like all the peeps who would frequent the Handlebar, hang out down here when the wallet's thin or something.  It is a short bike ride away, I guess. All in all.  Good food.  Good price.  Healthy.  Great options if you're vegetarian, and some kick-a stuff if you like meat.  You can also buy your groceries there to make the same stuff at home if you dare. Fun with friends too.

Great-tasting middle eastern grub and cheap, too.  This place was very clean.  There are a handful of seats but otherwise it's a good takeout option.  The falafel sandwich is good but the hummus lacked a little flavor.  I guess I am used to extreme amounts of garlic in my hummus.  I need a breath mint just thinking about it.

Totally delicious array of inexpensive Middle Eastern food! Falafel sandwiches were huge, nicely spicy and filling. Lamb schwarma also very good. Excellent creamy hummus. Salad bar looked extremely tempting and fresh. Can't wait to come back when (if) it warms up to load up for a picnic in the park.
Simply put... if you're in Lincoln Park  and you like hummus and fallafel... this is the place. Oh, and their meat pie is delicious. Yummm.

Fast quick cheap flavorful food.  Big portion radically good humus and they give you tons of that to.  Went with the Swarma Dinner.  For the fast quick meal one of the true signs of if it was good and good for you is how you feel an hour after you eat it.  I feel wonderful still full and satisfied after a big meal and no were close to needing a nap. Hit it up

perfectly standard and a good place to grab a reasonably priced yet still tasty schwarma sandwich.  Very filling, the lentil soup's not bad either.  What cracks me up is that they use sriracha in their sandwiches to up the spice factor.  I've never had asian hot sauce in a pita before, but it's pretty good!  the application is sometimes uneven however, so watch out!

It takes hard work to make middle-eastern food completely bland.  Somehow they've managed to do it at Sultan's.  (I had the kefta sandwich....the kefta tasted like canned meatballs and the "tahini" sauce was anything but...real pita bread shouldn't be "doughy" either). 2 stars because it was filling and somewhat reasonable.

This place is good for a quick bite to eat.  You cant really sit there.  I had the chicken schwarma once and the falafel the next time.  They are both good for the price (cheap).  Not the best - but it will definetly fill you up and is fast.   I personally feel there are plenty of better options in the same area - but nothing that cheap (other than the new empanada place down the street).

This is another great place for a quick bite. Every time I come here I get the Kefta Kabob sandwich. It is really good. I just love the lamb  and you have to get the spicy sauce in it as well. I can't really speak for the rest of the menu since this is the only thing I ever get.

Good food - great selection. This is a great place, the sister store of their North Ave location. The employees are nice and patient, and the food comes quickly and for a reasonable price.  Check out the salad bar if you are good at making your own, or, just ask the employees for selections.

Good falafal sami. It seemed great the first time, but the second time around, I'm re-thinking it. The lamb schwarma was not my fav. The meat was hard and not too tasty. Next time I'll stick with the chicken. We stopped in around 5, by this time, the spinach pie was looking like the heat lamps had sucked all the grease out of it and left a hard shell of a pie. Oddly enough, that was probably my fav item of the night. The crust was crispy. The filling was rich with spinach (the middle is the thickest part), but personally I like the cripy crust. It's quick food (took under 5 minutes to put 1 falafal and 1 schwarma together), don't expect to wait unless there's a line.  Overall, it's a good deal for the price and expedient service.

I was craving lamb this Sultan's fulfilled my request.  I had the lamb shawerma and it definitely hit the spot.  They do have a pretty killer salad bar, although I was unsure how good the food would stay sitting at what appeared to be at room temperature... one of those foods was shrimp.  Also $5.99 seems a bit steep for a salad bar, but to each their own.  Also what I wish was there were sides, other than potato chips to go with the sandwich.  Also the establishment is really small, with little to nowhere to eat.  The counter that is there so when sitting down comes to your shoulders, so it does make an awkward meal.  Overall I will definitely go back, but probably only for some takeout.

HOW MUCH HUMMUS CAN A PERSON EAT? OMG !! They have mastered this ChickPea stuff. YUMMY !  Prices even a 1st grader can afford. I have always been treated with a smile here. OH..I almost forgot about the salad bar. Always fresh and lots to choose from.  Only once did l order the fish special, and, well...just stay away from the fish specials.  Other then that I have a new favorite everytime I go.

This place was very good. I had a falafel sandwich, my husband had the chicken shwarma sandwich and we split an order of small hummus. The pitas were fresh and good, the hummus isn't like most hummus I am used to but was still very good (and a HUGE portion for only $4!) The only downsides are that the place is insanely small and it seems like the falafel was only mildly warm (under heat lamps) but it wasn't greasy, the service was good, and the food was awesome tasting so I can't complain too much!

I'm an addict with a problem. The problem is Sultan's Market and their amazing food. Very inexpensive and thus always a consideration for lunch or dinner. I seriously go into this place and change my mind about 20 times before I actually order. I'm always disappointed when I finish, not because the food is bad but the fact that I'm too full to have both shwaramas and the falafel! I never really considered the employees beyond average but this weekend I saw the man at the register give one of the patrons his lunch for free because he left his wallet at work, whether he was lying or not (he looked pretty honest to me) that was incredibly generous to help him out and I'm sure he got a customer for life or at least one more. 2 downsides: The drinks are way overpriced and the seating is horrendous, no tables like the wicker park location. I've had to stand on more than one occasion here.

Great cheap food! $4 for a very full falafel pita sandwich! My boyfriend got the kefta sandwich (lamb) which was so flavorful! The salad bar looks great with a lot of options, grape leaves, shrimp, squid, great fresh vegetables; but all the non-traditional items are very under seasoned, bland and probably should be passed up, especially if you are on the cheaper side of life. The Jerusalem salad that is a salad by itself is also on their sandwiches is really great.

I went to the Sultun's Market on Clark and the guy making our food had a "Bangbros" hat on. We sat and ate and another guy came in and asked where he got that hat, if he could order one too. The guy behind the counter (making our food) replied, "I work for them". A) I didn't know Bangbros had an outfit here in Chicago. B) He looked way too young to be anything like an accountant or marking director for them but did look like a "on screen" person. C) I wish he wouldn't have handled my food. D) The fallafel was still great but the atmosphere is way better at the other store, but this store takes credit cards!

I'm 3.5 months pregnant and since I moved to Chicago, a week ago, I've been here three times. The VEGAN rice and lentils is great and the falafel sandwich on pita is marvelous.  It's not super cheap, but it's decent. At least you get filled. I do think they accept credit cards now... I may be wrong.

The chicken shawarma was fantastic even though a few pieces of meat seemed a little questionable. As noted previously the drinks are canned and overpriced. The hummus is top notch. Very fast delivery.

This is my new favorite go-to place.  The service is quick and the food is great.  The chicken schwarma is the best I've had (get extra spicy) and the hummus is top notch.  I'd also give a thumbs up to the lentil soup.  They have a great salad bar with good grape leaves and a nice brussels sprouts salad.  Perfect for food on the run--or take out.  There are only a few stools and a window-bar, so don't go to this place expecting to have a long dining experience.  But, if you want to do some people watching on Clark Street then pull up a stool.

The food here was delicious.  I got the chicken schwarma (I think that's right) sandwich.  It had excellent flavor and a little spice to it as well.  The hummus was very good too.  The price was affordable.  The service was fair.  The employees were nice, but seemed more engulfed in their own conversations rather than actually interact with the customers.

I was very impressed with the speed of the whole process, he basically had my sandwich done by the time I had finished ordering it! The food was ok, nothing great, but for the price (I paid $5.50 for a sandwich and a pepsi!), it was adequate.

I am going to give this place another chance...we went there pretty late in the evening I think they were almost through for the night. Did manage to snag Falafals and Chicken Shawerma. I have to say I cant beat the price.. 2 chicken shawermas and 2 falafals were about 15 bucks. I wasn't hugely impressed tho, the chicken seemed a bit fatty and not very fresh. My husband was actually sick the same evening.. which is surprising, he has an iron stomach. But when I go back I think I will try the falafal only. Cant beat the price.
I crave Sultan's all the time!  Great hummus, great chicken schwarma, great falafel!  I recommend getting it with a little spice added too.  You can't lose - big portions enough to split.

We come here all the time. Chicken schwarma is marinated just right and sandwiches are pitas stuffed with hummus, cucumber, and tomato, instead of the usual lettuce. Slightly more expensive than other middle eastern quick food places, but worth it.

I had to check this place out after hearing about their falafel. I have to say, it's up there as one of the best falafel sandwiches I've had in the city. 4 bucks isn't bad a for a big pita stuffed with falafel and hummus. My boyfriend and I split it and got the small side of hummus which we couldn't even finish.  It is a very small joint, definitely better for take out. I had to wait in line awhile but I had no problem with it. There was only one guy working and he was going super fast trying to take care of everyone. I wanted to step back there and help him!  I also tried the lychee soda, not too bad! I'm definitely heading back, it's a great cheap eat.

Ok, I'm going to eat my own words and post about a chain (see the thread I posted earlier). I see the light, Yelpers! And must point out inconsistencies.  This is my lunch spot daily and as such, I know the falafel runs me exactly $4.41. A bit pricey for not having meat in it, not to mention the insance price of the poorly-stocked salad bar at $5.99/lb! Back to the meal- The falafel is generally cold, pita not warm and never any yummy sauce, unlike my fave PITA INN! On the plus side, you can get a large lentil soup for $3.31. (got that today) On to my gripe- after roughly 6 days of paying with my card for my falafel, the meany who runs the confusing cash register informed me that the minimum charge for cards is $5. That's fine, but don't tell me when Mr. Meany and I know each other by face and he's well aware that I've been paying with my card for over a week straight. POST IT IF YOU'VE GOT A MINIMUM CHARGE FOR CARDS! Grrr! Very annoying. Since I rarely carry cash and keep better track of my spending using my debit card and online banking, this is a particularly big deal for me.  Plus Mr. Meany always gives me dirty looks when I respond "No" when he asks if I'd like to buy a drink. Another minus 1 star- don't pressure me to buy your overpriced, canned drinks!

Having lived across the street for almost a year, I just recently went in, wished I would have gone earlier. Superb. I have eaten here 4 times in less than two weeks.  Sandwiches taste great, filling, fresh, and inexpensive. I have tried the falafel, lamb, chicken, and kefta; all delicious.  Another great thing about Sultan's is that you can walk in, order, and have your food in less 3 minutes. I would be willing to bet if you live close to this place you could actually go during a commercial and be back before missing anything.

The chicken schwarma sandwich here is YUM-MY.  And, they have some of the best hummus around!   Unfortunately, I can't give them 5 stars after a bad experience there the other night.  The moral of the story is, don't go in at 9:45 pm when they close at 10.  The chicken on our sandwich was not very warm and very fatty.  We also tried the lamb since they ran out of chicken, and I just wasn't a fan - again, very fatty.   But, I'm sure I'll give them another chance because the chicken schwarma sandwich was just that good every other time.  You do know I'll be going for lunch though!  Otherwise, I'll stick to the pita and hummus and maybe I'll try the falafel that I've heard is some of the best.

BEST CHICKEN SHWARMA EVER!!! So, this place is relatively new in LP, so I went in to get some hummus [which is very tasty and authentic, btw, not like the crap you get at Dominick's.]  I told the guy that I'd try the chicken shwarma next time, and he offered to give me a sample.  He put a nice amount in a plastic cup for me to try... OMG.  A-MAZING.  I can't wait to go back and get it!  Very nice people, too.
Best falafel in Chicago.  Great price....fast service.  The rice and Jerusalem salad is great also.

The food here made me feel like I was back in Israel (although they left out the "chips" on top of the sandwiches!). The chicken schwarma sandwich was awesome and the humous is so good... this place is a great alternative to Pita Inn. The only downside is it is only good for takeout- it is too small to eat in.

Amazing falafel sandwich!!! I'm used to Pita Inn and being able to make my own sandwich, but I will gladly let Sultan's make me another one, and very soon please. I also tried the chicken schwarma sandwich and that was awesome as well. The chicken was extremely tender.  This place is really only good for take out on the downside. I've heard about the bucktown location that has seating and all. I feel like if they got rid of the salad bar in the place, maybe they could set up a few little tables. But, I guess I'll pick it up from now on. One last thing. When we got there, I could see the falafel chillin under the hot lamps, as they were already made. Hmm, this in no way affected my awesome sandwich, but could it have been better if it had just come out of the fryer? Inquiring minds would like to know.
Glad to have the Lincoln Park outpost of the Wicker park original close by.  Can't go wrong with the lamb schwarma or falafel sandwiches.  Easy on the wallet as well.

I love living around the corner from this gem. Everyone says that they have the best falafel in the city and I can't disagree with that. They can also make the shwerma wraps extra spicy with SRIRACHA! I love sriracha so this always makes my day. If the lamb is not spinning on the spindle, it tends to be dry. If it's still cooking on the spindle, welcome to your new life. The people here are always super friendly and talkative too.

i would recommend you to stop by and take-out. you wouldn't want eat in here. it is cute, but you'll have a manic episode after experiencing extreme clausterphobia. falafel stuffed with vegen treasures. delectably spiced to NOT overbear ur tastebuds. and it's huge.. this sandwich is a meal. a big hearty meal. and at $4, i can't complain. (= this store has an array of the goods foreign foods (note soley middle-eastern). soy milk, that vietnamese spicey sauce, dates, fruit leather.. it could ur healthy heaven.. or nirvana.

Holy ssssshhhhh!t  Chalk this up to being a old-school whiner, but I do recall the days of paying $2 for a falafel sandwich at the Sultan's on North.  The same sandwich will now run you $4.40 with tax at this TINY location.   I guess they're figuring "whatever, the trixies at this location will pay it" which maybe be accurate, but is too bad.  I guess they have to account for the insane computer register system they put in here, which slows down everything ten-fold.

Yummy yummy yummy. I love the hummus, falafel, and everything. They carry the apricot paste my mom used to give me when I was little! Its really good- if you don't think about it being apricot paste. Its rolled out flat and leather like- like those fruit leathers- and in orange wrapping. Look for it and try it.  The service was really good where they make the sandwiches. Its tiny, but a great little place to pick up fun mediterranean food. Downside was they only accept cash, but that may have changed since my last visit.

I stumbled across this place the other week and thought the name sounded familiar - then realized I could see what all the kids in Wicker Park love to rave about.  I keep going back for the chicken shawerma pita - which is delicious, and they really load it up - but someday I'll get around to checking out the falafel.   The people running it are friendly and service is quick.  Never stayed to eat there since I live so close, but there usually seems to be a seat or two open. I don't really compare this to Aladdin's up the street since I mostly get the rolled pitas up there (which rock), but the pitas here are of the more traditional variety.  Not quite as good as I've had in Israel but definitely the best I've had in the States.

Sultan's prices are good, I will give them that. And when I tried some free samples, I was impressed enough to want it again, in larger quantities. I wanted it to be good again, I really really did. But I was sadly disappointed. I felt the quality of the food wasn't up to par, even compared to a chain like Aladdin's. I had the Falafel sandwich, which I thought would be warm, nope. Cold. It even said in the description, a "warm pita with..." And I thought it was too salty, and I am a fan of salt, so that is saying something! My husband thought his sandwich was too salty as well.  Also the falafel was crunchy on the outside, not a good crunchy, an over cooked tough crunchy. Not my thing. I also ordered the lentil soup with red lentils and red bell peppers etc. What I opened up looked and tasted like pea soup. It was good, don't get me wrong, but I saw no whole lentils, no red pepper and it was green. I could be way off, but that didn't seem right to me! But you can't beat the prices, 3 dollars for a large soup, sandwiches from 3 to 5 dollars, the most expensive thing was 7 dollars! They did have some nice vegan and vegetarian options, which is always good to see.   But I didn't finish my falafel sandwich and was too paranoid to finish the soup. So even though it was cheap, it was a bit of a waste. And I don't like to waste! I am a happy member of the clean plate club! I maybe would give it another try, but i think i would rather keep looking for that perfect Middle Eastern place.

Another Sultan's???  Am I in heaven??? Now I can have the exalted falafel sandwich when I'm at work on Friday in Lincoln Park, and AGAIN on Saturday when I wake up hung over in Wicker Park! And the prices at the new Lincoln Park location?.....  the same. yeaaaa.
